thread.title: David Miliband: Jeremy Corbyn has led Labour to its weakest point in half a century | London Evening Standard
thread.title_full: David Miliband: Jeremy Corbyn has led Labour to its weakest point in half a century | London Evening Standard

author: Saphora Smith
title: David Miliband: Jeremy Corbyn has led Labour to its weakest point in half a century | London Evening Standard
text:
Saturday 25 February 2017 13:20 GMT Click to followThe Evening Standard David Miliband has said he is 'deeply concerned' about the future of the Labour party Getty Images 
David Miliband has said he is “deeply concerned” for Labour’s future as Jeremy Corbyn’s policies have led the party to its weakest point in half a century. 
The former foreign secretary said Labour’s shift to the left under Mr Corbyn was a “mistake” which will not address the challenges Britain faces. 
His comments come as Mr Corbyn resists fresh calls to resign following a humiliating by-election defeat at the hands of the Tories in the Cumbrian seat of Copeland. 
Mr Miliband, who was narrowly beaten to the leadership by his brother Ed in 2010, called on Labour to "understand the historic nature of the challenge" it now faces, with a recent opinion poll putting the party 18 points behind the Tories. 
But he refused to join the calls for Mr Corbyn to stand down. 
In an interview with The Times Mr Miliband said: "I always say to people, 'Play the ball not the man.' So, 'What do I think of Jeremy Corbyn?' is not the question I ask myself. The question is, 'What do I think of the strategy?' 
"The tempting thing to say is that it's a mistake because it won't get elected but for people like me it's a mistake because it won't address the challenges of the country. 
"This isn't just an electability question, it's a question of substance. I think one can achieve more radical and substantive change through a different set of positions." Labour MPs turn on Jeremy Corbyn after by-election poll disaster 
Mr Miliband, who is now based in the United States as the head of aid charity the International Rescue Committee, also revealed he would have joined the 52 Labour MPs who rebelled against Mr Corbyn's three-line whip ordering MPs to back the European Union (Notification of Withdrawal) Bill. 
He said: "I would have found it very difficult to vote for that because I think that Article 50 needed to be triggered but my fear is that the terms under which it's going to be triggered will be very damaging. 
"I fear that we are going to end up with a higher chance of a disastrous outcome than is comfortable and I fear that we are going to end up with a harder outcome than is desirable." 
He also refused to rule-out a return to British politics. He told the paper: “I honestly don’t know what I am going to do. It’s hard to see – but what’s the point of saying never?” More about:
